Hi Jean 

I was pondering your first issue: 

> 1. I need to know the corre=
ct result from the other way around and 
sometimes it's hard to find anothe=
r way. 

I am not quite sure if I fully understand what you mean. Are you 
=
saying, to write good test, you need two different "approaches" to 
solve t=
he problem under test? Like in the following, trivial 
example: 

 public i=
nt multiply(int a, int b) {
  return a * b;
 }

 public void testMultiply()=
 {
  // test the expected result, "the other way round"
  assertEquals(5 + =
5, x.multiply(5, 2);
 }

I can see that this can get quite hard for non-tri=
vial problems. 

If this is what you meant, I think I have good news: In be=
lieve this 
rigorous approach to unit testing is not necessary. It's perfer=
ctly 
accaptable to just write the test as: 

  assertEquals(5 * 2, x.multi=
ply(5, 2);

The point of automated unit testing is not to prove algorithmic=
 
correctness but just to check real behavior against expected 
behavior. I=
n my opinion, the main benefit of _automated_ unit 
testing is to be able t=
o re-run the tests after implementation 
changes. And, after implementation=
 changes, you cannot be sure 
if "the other way round" is still another way=
 or if it has actually 
become "the way". So don't bother in the first plac=
e, and save a lot 
of time and pain. 

Again: For me, automated unit tests =
are primarily like an insurance 
against quality degradation when I change =
code. They are less 
important to prove correctness of the initial version =
of the code I 
write. I tend to spend more time changeing existing code tha=
n 
writing new code, so that's fine for me. 

Bottom line is, forget about =
the "other way round" issue. ;-) 

Hasko
